Award.AwardTitle: Measurement and Control of Dynamic Weld Pool Surface in Gas Metal Arc Welding

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to (1) simultaneously measure the three-dimensional shape of weld pool surface and the growth, detachment and trajectory of molten metal droplets in gas metal arc welding, and (2) use the simultaneous measurements to test the hypothesis that the weld pool surface is controlled by the arc and droplet characteristic parameters. The approach is to (1) image the specular reflection of a projected laser from the weld pool surface to simultaneously measure the weld pool surface and droplet characteristic parameters, (2) use the arc and droplet characteristic parameters to adjust the weld pool surface shape, and (3) use the required arc and droplet characteristic parameters to determine how to change the welding parameters.

Gas metal arc welding is the most widely used process in automatic welding. The completion of the research will be of significant help in better understanding this complex process and provide the foundation to develop next generation intelligent welding machines. The multi-disciplinary research and collaborative activities will provide participating graduate and undergraduate students with opportunities to lead the change of manufacturing industry from being a "low-tech" to high-tech industry. Also, a high school senior would join in the challenging research and thus may be attracted to the engineering field. The research would also provide excellent materials for senior design projects. The development of the special website will provide a step-by-step procedure to guide researchers around the world to build the sensor for their research.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Observing and measuring the 3D weld pool surface in gas metal arc welding (GMAW) is a major key to understanding and controlling this most-widely used yet complex welding process for the next generation manufacturing. First, the quality of the welds produced, especially the weld joint penetration, is directly associated with the geometry of the 3D weld pool surface because skilled welders can adjust welding parameters to produce quality welds based on their observation on the weld pool. Second, physical phenomena occurring during GMAW are so complex that their in-depth understanding demands numerous models. Unfortunately, numerical models need measurements from the actual process including the weld pool surface to confirm and validate. While a vision-based measurement offers a preferred direct method to measure the 3D weld pool surface, the presence of the extraordinary radiation of the arc together with the specular nature and the highly dynamic characteristic of weld pool surface in GMAW introduces challenges.

This research answered all the major fundamental questions related to the optical nature of the specular weld pool surface in GMAW, established the foundation for vision-based direct measurement of the specular weld pool surface in GMAW, and experimentally demonstrated the effectiveness of the systematic solutions established using this foundation for the preferred direct measurement. Major fundamental discoveries and findings from this research include: (1) The weld pool surface in gas metal arc welding (GMAW) is indeed also specular and does reflect projected laser patterns similarly as a mirror and a gas tungsten arc weld pool surface such that reflections of projected laser patterns in GMAW can also be clearly imaged despite the presence of the extreme arc radiation. (2) The weld pool fluctuation is the major factor affecting the imaging of the reflection patterns in GMAW. Clearly imaging the laser pattern reflected from such a fluctuating weld pool surface requires the exposure time for imaging to be sufficiently small such that the spatial change of the laser pattern reflected from it is negligible in this exposure time period. It also requires the intensity of the projected laser pattern to be sufficient corresponding to the sensitivity of the imaging sensor at the laser waveform. (3) The frequency of the fluctuation of the weld pool surface in GMAW is primarily determined by the droplet impingement in addition to the altering arc pressure that is determined by the pulsed current. (4) The droplet in GMAW can be simultaneously imaged with the weld pool surface if the reflected laser pattern is, or is intentionally made to be, partially blocked by the droplet. (5) Reflections of projected laser patterns can be used to reconstruct the weld pool surface in GMAW. Use of a grid laser pattern can speed the weld pool reconstruction and improve the reconstruction accuracy in GMAW.

In the broader impact, this research established part of the foundation for the development of the next generation intelligent welding machines that help US manufacturing industry to compete with other manufacturing industries that enjoy relatively low labor costs. It provided the welding research community a direct tool to observe, understand, and study the most widely used yet difficult to observe, understand, and study welding process. This research also provided an innovative method that can be effectively used to develop an industrial system to control the weld joint penetration in GMAW only using the arc electronic signals through correlating the arc electrical signals to the weld pool surface that determines the weld joint penetration. In education, this research yielded two high quality PhD dissertation research projects and provided challenging topics to train a post-doctoral researcher and an undergraduate researcher from an under-represented group. The chall...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Observing and measuring the 3D weld pool surface in gas metal arc welding (GMAW) is a major key to understanding and controlling this most-widely used yet complex welding process for the next generation manufacturing. First, the quality of the welds produced, especially the weld joint penetration, is directly associated with the geometry of the 3D weld pool surface because skilled welders can adjust welding parameters to produce quality welds based on their observation on the weld pool. Second, physical phenomena occurring during GMAW are so complex that their in-depth understanding demands numerous models. Unfortunately, numerical models need measurements from the actual process including the weld pool surface to confirm and validate. While a vision-based measurement offers a preferred direct method to measure the 3D weld pool surface, the presence of the extraordinary radiation of the arc together with the specular nature and the highly dynamic characteristic of weld pool surface in GMAW introduces challenges. This research answered all the major fundamental questions related to the optical nature of the specular weld pool surface in GMAW, established the foundation for vision-based direct measurement of the specular weld pool surface in GMAW, and experimentally demonstrated the effectiveness of the systematic solutions established using this foundation for the preferred direct measurement. Major fundamental discoveries and findings from this research include: (1) The weld pool surface in gas metal arc welding (GMAW) is indeed also specular and does reflect projected laser patterns similarly as a mirror and a gas tungsten arc weld pool surface such that reflections of projected laser patterns in GMAW can also be clearly imaged despite the presence of the extreme arc radiation. (2) The weld pool fluctuation is the major factor affecting the imaging of the reflection patterns in GMAW. Clearly imaging the laser pattern reflected from such a fluctuating weld pool surface requires the exposure time for imaging to be sufficiently small such that the spatial change of the laser pattern reflected from it is negligible in this exposure time period. It also requires the intensity of the projected laser pattern to be sufficient corresponding to the sensitivity of the imaging sensor at the laser waveform. (3) The frequency of the fluctuation of the weld pool surface in GMAW is primarily determined by the droplet impingement in addition to the altering arc pressure that is determined by the pulsed current. (4) The droplet in GMAW can be simultaneously imaged with the weld pool surface if the reflected laser pattern is, or is intentionally made to be, partially blocked by the droplet. (5) Reflections of projected laser patterns can be used to reconstruct the weld pool surface in GMAW. Use of a grid laser pattern can speed the weld pool reconstruction and improve the reconstruction accuracy in GMAW. In the broader impact, this research established part of the foundation for the development of the next generation intelligent welding machines that help US manufacturing industry to compete with other manufacturing industries that enjoy relatively low labor costs. It provided the welding research community a direct tool to observe, understand, and study the most widely used yet difficult to observe, understand, and study welding process. This research also provided an innovative method that can be effectively used to develop an industrial system to control the weld joint penetration in GMAW only using the arc electronic signals through correlating the arc electrical signals to the weld pool surface that determines the weld joint penetration. In education, this research yielded two high quality PhD dissertation research projects and provided challenging topics to train a post-doctoral researcher and an undergraduate researcher from an under-represented group.
